background: Carl struggles with controlling his reactions in challenging situations.
pre_reasoning: The therapist uses questions to help Carl break down his responses into manageable steps, providing him with a practical map for future actions. This directive approach aims to give Carl more control and clarity.

dialog.text: Something like that.
Something like that? Before you reach a point of having to react.

Yeah, but sometimes, like when a body is in a situation, it’s steadfast, you know, it’s, you know, in place. I usually listen to what he’s telling me, and then it goes through my brain, and then whatever comes out, it comes out. And that’s what I’m scared of, because sometimes you can say the wrong words to somebody.
That’s right.
That’ll, you know …
Trigger something.
But you know, yeah, in that kind of situation, it’s unstoppable.
Right.
Especially with him, he’s just …
Yeah.
I mean, there was a time where I was scared of him. I’m a little scared of him now, of what he kind of would do to me, but I’m mostly scared of what I’m going to do to him.
Ah.
So, I’m trying to avoid that the best way I can.
Wow, amazing, amazing. So what would be the first small sign that would tell you, “Uh-oh, I better walk away?”
The first sign …
The first small sign that tells you, “This is a dangerous situation.”
A small sign would be my heart pounding.
Okay.
That happens all the time. If I’m arguing with somebody, my heart pounds and pounds. That’s dangerous.
So when you feel that …
Yeah.
… you say, “This is time to get out.”
Yeah, that’s a warning sign.
That’s a warning sign.
But then, once stuff comes out of my mouth, my head starts to hurt. That’s the other sign.
Yeah.
That’s the bad one, like, that’s when the conflict comes in.
Okay, so by the time your head starts to hurt, is that too late?
No.
Or do you still have time?
I still have time.
You still have time to walk away.
Like, last night, I actually hit my head and snapped out of it and said, “I’m going to cool off.” So basically, I sort of got in control for the first time.
Yes, you did.
This is the first time …
Yes, you did.
… that I actually got in control.
Yes, you did. Right. So, the heart pounding is the first sign.
The head hurting …
The head hurts is the second sign. Something coming out of your mouth is the third sign.
And then, trying to avoid that, I try to either hit my head or try to snap out of it.
Snap out of it.
Or try to go outside or something.
What do you mean, hit your head?
As in, you know … you know, somebody try to snap, you know, slap somebody out of their, you know, coma or something.
So, you go like that?
reference_labels: [Gestures as if hitting the side of her head.]

dialog.text: Yeah, I’ll go like that real, real hard and I’ll just be—
Real hard?
Real hard, and I’ll say, “I’m going to go cool off.”
Okay, and that’s a signal to you?
Right.
So that’s step three, it sounds like.
Yeah.
Yeah.
In between.
In between, right. So you have some time to walk out the door?
Exactly. But sometimes it doesn’t work; this time it worked, but other times, it’s just step one and two.
Okay, all right. So which is safest? What step do you need to act if it is the safest? Step one, heart pounding, heart pounding, headache, or something coming out of your mouth?
Oh, it’s my heart, all the time.
The heart?
Your heart is your key to life, actually. I mean, if it beats harder, something is wrong, even if it’s something good like adrenalin, like you’re on a roller-coaster ride or something like that.
You’re right.
The heart pounding is, you know, you having fun or something like that. But the heart pounding when you’re off in that type of situation, you should just, you know, leave, and I’m going to do that.
Okay. That’s a signal to you?
Yeah.
“Uh-oh, danger is coming.”
Right. I’ll just get out then.
Get out.
Instead of trying to listen to what he has to say.
Right, right.
Yeah.
Okay. How confident are you that you can do this? When your heart pounds, “Uh-oh, get out?”

post_reasoning: This session focuses on assessing safety and determining further steps for improvement.
